revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = El pueblo unido jamás será vencido | cover = El pueblo unido jamás será vencido single.jpg | alt = | caption = Cover of the 7" vinyl release | type = single | artist = [[Quilapayún]] | album = [[El Pueblo Unido Jamás Será Vencido (album)|El Pueblo Unido Jamás Será Vencido]] | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | B-side = Chacarilla | released = {{Start date|1975}} | format = | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = | label = Movieplay | composer = [[Sergio Ortega]] | lyricist = [[Quilapayun]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} '''"¡El pueblo unido, jamás será vencido!"''' ({{IPA-es|el ˈpweβlo uˈniðo xaˈmas seˈɾa βenˈsiðo|am}}; <small>[[English language|English]]</small>: "The people united will never be defeated") is one of the most internationally renowned songs of the ''[[Nueva canción|Nueva cancion chilena]]'' (New Chilean Song) movement. The music of the song was composed by [[Sergio Ortega]] and the text written by [[Quilapayún]]. The song was composed and recorded in June 1973.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newalbion.com/NA063/ |title=Frederic Rzewski: The People United Will Never Be Defeated! |accessdate=2007-04-13 |publisher=New Albion Records}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.trovadores.net/lmveure.php?NM=4&PC=9 |title=LA NUEVA CANCIÓN CHILENA by José Manuel García |accessdate=2009-05-12 |publisher=Cancioneros.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205031644/http://www.trovadores.net/lmveure.php?NM=4 |archivedate=2007-02-05 |df= }}</ref>
== History == The song was initially composed as an anthem for the [[Popular Unity (Chile)|popular unity]] government, reflecting the spirit behind the mass mobilization of working-class people who in 1970 [[Chilean presidential election, 1970|had elected]] [[Salvador Allende]] for the [[socialist]] transformation of Chile. During Allende's campaign ''El pueblo unido jamás será vencido'' was a frequent slogan.<ref>Corvalán, Luis (2003) [https://books.google.com/books?id=3IschSI-zG8C&pg=PA111 El gobierno de Salvador Allende], pp.111-2</ref><ref>Wessel, Günther (2002) [https://books.google.com/books?id=bJ2-wUrZn8IC&pg=PA102 ''Los Allende: con ardiente paciencia por un mundo mejor''], pp.102-3</ref> The song was interpreted and recorded by a number of music groups shortly after it was composed and performed publicly by [[Sergio Ortega]] and [[Quilapayún]]. ''New Chilean Song'' music ensembles such as Vientos del Pueblo, [[Inti-illimani]] among others, made successful recordings of the song that filled the airways and the backgrounds of political rallies. After the U.S.-backed<ref name="PINOCHET: A Declassified Documentary Obit">{{cite web|title= PINOCHET: A Declassified Documentary Obit |author=Kornbluh, Peter |publisher=gwu.edu |date=2006-12-12 |url=http://www.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB212/index.htm|accessdate=2007-01-06 |authorlink= Peter Kornbluh}}</ref> [[1973 coup in Chile|September 11, 1973 Chilean coup]] the song became the anthem of the Chilean resistance against the [[Pinochet]] regime, both within Chile and among the community of Chilean [[exile]]s and their political allies abroad.
However, it was especially after [[1973 Chilean coup d'état|Pinochet's September 1973 coup]] that the group [[Inti-Illimani]] (also from Chile) made it famous around the world, after they published the song in the album [[La Nueva Canción Chilena (Inti-Illimani 2)|La Nueva Canción Chilena]].
During the course of time the song has been used in various protests around the world, most of which have no direct connection to the Chilean coup or [[Latin America]]. The lyrics have been adapted or translated into many languages.
== Versions == *In a more militant version, the phrase ''El pueblo unido jamás será vencido'' is changed in the last verse to ''El pueblo armado jamás será aplastado'' — "The people armed will never be crushed".<ref>{{YouTube|MBm2debqePc|Los Miserables - El Pueblo Unido}}</ref> *In [[Portugal]], especially from 1974 to 1977, pro-democracy, populist, centrist and left-wing groups (especially communists) sang a song called ''Portugal Ressuscitado'' (Resurrected Portugal), written by [[Ary dos Santos]] and sung by [[Fernando Tordo]] and an accompanying chorus. The song was recorded immediately after the [[Carnation Revolution]]<ref>[[:pt:Fernando Tordo|Fernando Tordo - Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre]]</ref> with the famous encore ''Agora o Povo Unido nunca mais será vencido'' (Now the People United will never more be defeated).<ref>{{YouTube|QVKD_cxGlCE|Portugal Ressuscitado - 1977 - 25 Canções de Abril}}</ref> The song, though, had only very small similarities with the tune of the Chilean song during most of its structure except during the similar encore, and no lyrical similarity besides the spirit of popular struggle and the similar catchphrase/slogan. The song and the slogan are still quite popular and part of Portuguese collective memory.<ref>[http://blogportugalxxi.blogspot.com/2005/08/o-povo-est-desunido-por-isso.html O Povo está desunido, por isso é facilmente vencido...]</ref><ref>[https://tu-barao.blogs.sapo.pt/49976.html Segunda-feira, 16 de Julho de 2007, Está completamente apanhado!, Tubarão blog]</ref><ref>[http://recantodasletras.uol.com.br/poesias/1429415 Recanto das Letras, Cenas de Um Sonho], 09/02/2009 06h54 comment</ref> *In [[Iran]], the melody was used for a revolutionary song with [[Persian language|Persian]] lyrics, entitled "''Barpakhiz''" (in [[English language|English]] "Arise"),<ref>{{YouTube|Q-OC1NQpcHc|Barpakhiz_Shabahang.wmv}}</ref> with encore ''بر پا خیز، از جا کن، بنای کاخ دشمن!'' (Pronounced as ''Barpakhiz, az ja kan, banaye kakh-e doshman'', Meaning: ''Arise, Demolish the Foundations of the Enemy's Palace!'') by the Iranian leftist revolutionaries during [[Islamic Revolution|the Revolution against the monarchy in 1979]]. The song has experienced a revival in popularity with the [[Green Revolution (Iran)|Iranian Green revolution]] as a rally and protest song.<ref>{{YouTube|W9uHxTWt5OY|Bar Pa Khiz بر پا خيز}}</ref> *In the [[Philippines]], the song was loosely translated by the progressive band [[Patatag]] for their song "''Awit ng Tagumpay''" (which translates to "Song of Victory") with its Tagalog encore "''Tibayin ang hanay, Gapiin ang Kaaway!''" (Strengthen the ranks, destroy the oppressors). It is sung during demonstrations.<ref>{{YouTube|FJX4yQr8XmQ|Awit ng Tagumpay (Victory Song)}}</ref> The [[Bagong Alyansang Makabayan]] also used its loosely Tagalog translation of the title as its motto: "''Ang tao, ang bayan, ngayon ay lumalaban!''" *In 1975 [[Frederic Rzewski]] composed [[The People United Will Never Be Defeated!|36 piano variations]] on this song. *In 1977, the German folk singer [[Hannes Wader]] released the song "El pueblo unido" on the live album "Hannes Wader singt Arbeiterlieder" recorded at a folk festival organized by the [[German Communist Party|DKP]] newspaper [[Unsere Zeit]]. *In 1979, "[[The People United Will Never Be Defeated!]]" was chanted at the [[White Night riots]] after the sentencing of former [[San Francisco]] supervisor [[Dan White]] in the murders of [[George Moscone]] and [[Harvey Milk]]. White only served 5 years of a 7-year sentence. * In 1982, the American bassist [[Charlie Haden]] recorded a version with [[Carla Bley]] and the [[Liberation Music Orchestra]] on the album ''Ballad of the Fallen'' which was voted top jazz album of the year in Downbeat's 1984 critics' poll. * In 1983, during the "Resistance March" (Marcha de la resistencia) in Argentina, the song was revived with the lyrics "Resulta indispensable, aparición con vida y castigo a los culpables" ("It's essential that they return the disappeared, and that the guilty be punished"). The song was still being sung in the 2000s in Argentina with the disappearance of Julio Lopez. *In 1995 the Hungarian [[Ska]] group Szabad Idők (Free Times) released the song "El Pueblo Unido" on their album Vivan Los Zapatistas!. El Pueblo Unido included lyrics inspired by the Chilean song. *In 2002 Russian singer Garik Sukachev used the phrase in his song "Svobodu Anjele Davis" ("freedom for [[Angela Davis]]"). *In 2002 the group [[Ska-p]] released the song "Estampida" on their album [[¡¡Que Corra La Voz!!]]. Estampida included lyrics inspired by the Chilean song. *in 2003 the group [[Anti-Flag]] used the English translation "The people united will never be defeated" as chorus in the song "One People, One Struggle"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.songlyrics.com/anti-flag/one-people-one-struggle-lyrics/|title=ANTI-FLAG LYRICS - One People, One Struggle|last=|first=|date=|website=songlyrics.com|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-09}}</ref> from the album "[[The Terror State]]" *In 2004 Ukrainian rap band [[GreenJolly]] paraphrased this song to create "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty|Razom nas bahato]]" ("Together We Are Many") during the first days of [[Orange Revolution]]. This song was the Ukraine's entry at the [[2005 Eurovision Song Contest]]. * In 2007, during the Greek general elections, the song was used during the main campaign of the left party SYRIZA ([[Coalition of the Radical Left]]) and it figured on the party's televised message. *In 2008, [[Thievery Corporation]] released "El pueblo unido" on the album [[Radio Retaliation]], which is based on this quote. * In the [[2010–2011 Tunisian protests|protests in Tunis in 2010 and 2011]] that lead to the ousting of president [[Zine El Abidine Ben Ali|Ben Ali]], protesters chanted on the same rhythm the phrase "الشعب يريد إسقاط النظام" ([[Ash-shab yurid isqat an-nizam]]) which translates to "The people want the regime down". The same phrase was chanted for the first time in [[Tahrir square]] in Egypt on 25 January 2011 in what turned into [[2011 Egyptian revolution|massive protests]] that lead to the ousting of president [[Hosni Mubarak]]. *The 2012 [[Flobots]] album ''[[The Circle in the Square]]''{{'}}s titular track uses this line in its lyrics. *The 2013 song "[[Control (Big Sean song)|Control]]" by [[Big Sean]] featuring [[Kendrick Lamar]] and [[Jay Electronica]] samples the recording by [[Sergio Ortega]] and [[Quilapayún]] * In 2014, during the [[Sunflower Student Movement]] in Taiwan, this song was translated to Chinese as "{{lang|zh-Hant-TW|團結的人民永遠不被擊潰}}" by Huáng Sī-nóng and Jiăng Tāo. *The 2015 song El Pueblo Unido by Austrian [[ska-punk]] band [[Russkaja]] uses the line from original song in the chorus.* *In 2017 [[Wikipedia:wiki/Lowkey|Lowkey's]] Fire in the booth part 2 ends with a repetition of the words "El pueblo unido jamás será vencido" *In 1990, Turkish rock band [[Bulutsuzluk Ozlemi]] released the song "Şili'ye Özgürlük" (which translates to "Freedom to Chile") on their second album "Uçtu Uçtu". The song is included lyrics "El pueblo unido jamás será vencido".

{{advert|date=November 2017}} '''Fred Done''' (born March 1943)<ref name=CompaniesHouse>{{cite web|title=Betfred Limited|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/04815730/officers|website=Companies House|accessdate=29 July 2015}}</ref> is an English billionaire businessman, the co-owner with his brother [[Peter Done]] of the [[bookmaker|bookmaking]] chain [[Betfred]], which has more than 1,350 betting shops in the United Kingdom.
In February 2015, it was announced Fred Done was in talks to sell a 25% stake in the Tote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/betfred-founders-fred-and-peter-done-eye-sale-of-25-stake-in-the-tote-s88p09hpv|title=Betfred founders Fred and Peter Done eye sale of 25% stake in the Tote|last=Duke|first=Simon|date=2018-02-25|work=The Sunday Times|access-date=2018-07-30|language=en|issn=0956-1382}}</ref>
In April 2015, the ''[[Sunday Times]]'' estimated the brothers' joint net worth at £1.0 billion.<ref name="STRL">{{cite news|title=Sunday Times Rich List|work=The Sunday Times|issue=page 34|date=26 April 2014}}</ref>
In June 2018, Done has made an investment in the Nottingham-based online advertising platform Adzooma.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businesscloud.co.uk/news/adzooma-partners-with-google-to-help-smes-grow-online|title=Adzooma partners with Google to help SMEs grow online|website=BusinessCloud.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>

{{about|the bell in Berlin|the bell in Washington. D.C.|American Legion Freedom Bell}} [[Image:Berlin-Freiheitsglocke.JPG|thumb|upright=1.3|The Freedom Bell]] [[File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-P047199, Berlin, Schöneberger Sängerknaben.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Schoolchildren pose beneath the Freedom Bell, 1958]]
The '''Freedom Bell''' (in German, ''Freiheitsglocke'') in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]], is a [[bell (instrument)|bell]] that was given as a gift from [[United States|Americans]] to the city of Berlin in 1950 as a symbol of [[anti-communism]], and was inspired by the American [[Liberty Bell]]. Since 1950, the bell has been located in the [[Rathaus Schöneberg]], the former city hall of [[West Berlin]].
==Origins and installation== The initiative to give Berlin such a bell was taken by the ''Crusade for Freedom'', a propaganda campaign sponsored by the [[National Committee for a Free Europe]], the organization which operated [[Radio Free Europe]]. The campaign was launched by U.S. general [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] on Labor Day, 1950, with General [[Lucius D. Clay]], later known as the "father of the [[Berlin airlift]]", as its chairman. The stated purpose of the Campaign was to offer all Americans an opportunity to play a personal part in a demonstration of the "free world's determination to resist Communist aggression." The bell was conceived by Abbott Washburn and Nate Crabtree and designed by [[Walter Dorwin Teague]].<ref name="Cummings 2010 - Freedom Bell">{{cite news|last=Cummings|first=Richard H.|title=The Freedom Bell in Berlin (Updated March 2011)|url=http://coldwarradios.blogspot.com/2010/11/freedom-bell-in-berlin-updated-march.html|accessdate=20 September 2012|newspaper=Cold War Radios|date=29 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="Medhurst 1997">{{cite journal|last=Medhurst|first=Martin J.|title=Eisenhower and the Crusade for Freedom: The Rhetorical Origins of a Cold War Campaign|journal=Presidential Studies Quarterly|date=Fall 1997|volume=27|issue=4|pages=646–661|jstor=27551792 .}}</ref>
The 10-ton bell arrived from the British [[Bellfounding|bell foundry]] of [[Gillett & Johnston]] to a ticker tape parade in [[New York City]]. It carries the inscription ''That this world under God shall have a new birth of freedom''. The bell subsequently visited 26 American cities, and people in every state were encouraged to sign a "Declaration of Freedom".<ref>[http://www.sujet.de/sign/doku/freiheitsglocke/s5_e.html 50th Anniversary of the Freedom Bell in Berlin<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> 16 million signatures from American citizens were collected and are enshrined in Berlin along with the bell.<ref>[http://www.martinmdb.com/peacebells.html The Martins, World Bells of Peace and Freedom<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The bell then traveled to Berlin, and was permanently installed in the [[West Berlin]] city hall on [[United Nations Day]], October 24, 1950.<ref>http://www.dradio.de/dlf/sendungen/kalenderblatt/430825/ (in German)</ref> More than 400,000 Berliners filled the square before the city hall (now [[John-F.-Kennedy-Platz]]) to witness the dedication ceremonies. General Clay gave a speech and pushed the button that started the bell ringing. Its tones were heard throughout East Berlin and into East Germany. The East German [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany]] (SED) launched a demonstration several miles from the dedication site, and party members denounced the ball as a "war bell", a "hunger bell" and a "death bell". SED central committee member [[Hans Jendretzky]] warned: "The rope of the death bell will become the gallows rope for those who ring it."<ref name="Puddington">Arch Puddington, ''Broadcasting Freedom: The Cold War Triumph of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty'', 2003, p. 21</ref>
The Governing Mayor of West Berlin, [[Ernst Reuter]] ([[Social Democratic Party of Germany|SPD]]), declared that Germany "will never rest or relax until freedom will shine over the countries of Eastern Europe that are at present forced to live in slavery".<ref name="Puddington" />
==Occasions for ringing== The bell is rung daily at noon, and at midnight on [[Christmas Eve]] and on [[New Year's Eve]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berlin.de/ba-tempelhof-schoeneberg/derbezirk/wissenswertes/freiheitsglocke.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414175707/http://www.berlin.de/ba-tempelhof-schoeneberg/derbezirk/wissenswertes/freiheitsglocke.html |archivedate=2008-04-14 |df= }} (in German)</ref> A recording of the ringing was broadcast by [[Rundfunk im amerikanischen Sektor|RIAS]], the American radio in West Berlin, every Sunday just before noon. These broadcasts have been continued by the successor of RIAS, [[Deutschlandradio Kultur]]. In the radio broadcasts, the ringing of the bell is followed by an excerpt from the text of the "Declaration of Freedom" in [[German language|German]], read by prominent theatre actors.
The bell has also been rung on several special occasions: the 1953 [[Uprising of 1953 in East Germany|Uprising of June 17]], the 1956 [[Hungarian Uprising of 1956|Hungarian Uprising]], the construction of the [[Berlin Wall]] in 1961 and the [[Reunification of Germany]] of 1990. In 2001, the bell was rung on occasion of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]], and thousands of Berlin citizens paid their respect at [[John-F.-Kennedy-Platz]] in front of the former city hall of West Berlin.

{{more footnotes|date=October 2015}} <!--- Don't mess with this line! ---><!--- Write your article below this line ---> '''Gideon's Promise''', formerly the Southern Public Defender Training Center, is a non-profit organization founded in 2007. The organization is based in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], and provides ongoing continuing education programs for [[law school]] students, new [[public defender]]s, senior public defenders, law school clinicians and chief public defenders. The organization partners with [[public defender]] offices around the country to implement best practices in public defense. Gideon's Promise is dedicated to transforming the culture of the [[criminal justice system]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gray|first1=Katti|title=Defense Mode: Gideon's Promise Aims To Change The Face of Criminal Justice|url=http://www.essence.com/2015/03/26/defense-mode-gideons-promise-aims-change-face-criminal-justice|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=Essence|date=March 26, 2015}}</ref>
==Mission== Their mission is to transform the criminal justice system by building a movement of public defenders who provide equal justice for marginalized communities.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Michel|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=243213638|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=NPR|date=November 5, 2013}}</ref> Public defenders are necessary if we are to realize equal justice in America.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dwyer|first1=Liz|title=Here's What Happens When Public Defenders Are Overworked and Underpaid|url=http://www.takepart.com/article/2014/03/21/gideons-promise-shows-public-defenders-overworked-underpaid|accessdate=10 February 2016|publisher=Takepart|date=March 22, 2014}}</ref>
Gideon's Promise sees public defenders as the primary engine of change in the criminal justice system and thus they are the primary focus of our efforts. They seek to transform the culture of offices in the belief that it will affect both the larger criminal justice system and communities. The organization partners with public defender offices around the country to implement best practices while driving systemic reform.
==Programs== * Summer Law Clerk:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.law.ucla.edu/news-and-events/in-the-news/2014/05/UCLA-Law-Student-Selected-for-Gideons-Promise-Summer-Law-Clerk-Program/|website=UCLA Law|publisher=UCLA Law|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> Designed for law students who are interested in public defense who commit to volunteering during the summer months. * Core 101:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Archbold|first1=Hunt|url=http://patch.com/georgia/midtown/gideons-promise-announces-2014-law-school-partnership-program-recipients|website=Midtown Patch|publisher=Midtown Patch|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> A three-year program designed to provide new public defenders the skills and knowledge necessary to become excellent advocates for those they represent. The program lays the foundation for new public defenders. * Graduate 201:<ref>{{cite web|title=The Law School Partnership Project|url=http://files.equaljusticeworks.org/gideonspromiselawschoolpartnershipproject.pdf|website=Equal Justice Works|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> A three-year program available to any graduate of the Core "101" Program interested in joining the Gideon's Promise faculty and/or serve as supervising attorneys and mentors in their offices. * Leadership:<ref>{{cite web|title=Profile of Ilham Askia|url=http://www.publicdefenders.us/?q=user/364|website=National Association for Public Defense|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> Designed for chief defenders and leaders in local and state defender offices. * Trainer Development:<ref>{{cite web|title=Trainer Development|url=http://www.gideonspromise.org/programs/trainer-development|website=Gideon's Promise|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> Teaches participants the Gideon's Promise philosophy, model, and curriculum as well as skills and strategies for effectively teaching and mentoring public defenders working in challenging systems. * Law School Partnership:<ref>{{cite web|title=UCLA Law Student Receives Gideon's Promise Fellowship|url=https://www.law.ucla.edu/news-and-events/in-the-news/2015/04/UCLA-Law-Student-Receives-Gideons-Promise-Fellowship-to-Work-in-Richland-County-Public-Defenders-Office/|website=UCLA Law|accessdate=10 February 2016}}</ref> Partnership between Gideon's Promise, our partner public defender offices and law schools committed to justice. The fellowship program guarantees students full-time employment at one of our public defender office affiliates.
==Leadership== '''Jonathan Rapping''', president and founder of Gideon's Promise, is a nationally renowned criminal justice innovator and 2014 MacArthur Foundation "Genius" Fellow, who moved from Washington, D.C. to Atlanta, because he found the injustice within our criminal justice system – particularly in the South – to be unacceptable.
In 2007, Rapping founded Gideon's Promise and began an initiative to change the public defense landscape across America by grooming a generation of public defenders – many of whom are often so overwhelmed by crushing caseloads that they are unable to provide their clients the representation the Constitution demands – to rise up and fight against the injustice within our justice system.
In his quest to train and equip public defenders with the resources necessary to ensure all citizens receive their Constitutional right of "equal justice for all," Rapping and his organization have become symbols of a new civil rights movement.
Professor Rapping received a J.D. from the George Washington University School of Law, a M.P.A. from the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University, and a B.A. from the University of Chicago. He is currently a Professor at Atlanta's John Marshall Law School.
Jonathan Rapping was honored in 2014 as a MacArthur Fellow for his work with Gideon's Promise.
In the fall of 2014, president and founder [[Jonathan Rapping]] partnered with the state of Maryland in an attempt to improve statewide public defense. [[Jonathan Rapping]] was honored in 2014 as a [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur Fellow]] for his work with Gideon's Promise.
'''Ilham Askia''' is the co-founder of Gideon's Promise, and serves as the organization's executive director.
Askia was 5 years old when her father, although he had long since ended a life of crime to become a devout Muslim, was arrested on an armed robbery warrant. He was convicted and served 10 years in prison. Her father was served by a public defender. Whether it was due to lack of training or overwhelming case load, the public defender did not provide the court details of Askia's father's character change – important information that could have possibly led to an outcome other than prison. This is why Askia helped found Gideon's Promise.
Askia received a Masters in Teaching from Trinity University in Washington, D.C. and a B.S. from Cornell University.

[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/14/jonathan-rapping-gideons-promise_n_5147029.html "One Man's Fight To Change The Justice System"], ''[[Huffington Post]]'', D.C.,15 April 2014. * Camilerri, Ricky. [http://live.huffingtonpost.com/r/segment/gideons-army-hbo-documentary/51c1d74902a760294b00026c "Fighting The Deep South Criminal Justice System"], ''[[Huffington Post]]'', D.C., 24 June 2013. * MacArthur Foundation. [http://www.macfound.org/fellows/925/ "Meet the Class of 2014"], "[[MacArthur Foundation]]", Chicago, 17 September 2014.

The '''impeachment of Václav Klaus''' refers to a failed attempt by members of the [[Senate of the Czech Republic|Czech Senate]] to impeach the [[President of the Czech Republic]], [[Václav Klaus]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Czech President Vaclav Klaus faces treason charge |date=March 4, 2013 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-21660234 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=October 23, 2016}}</ref> The case was eventually dismissed by the court on the grounds that his mandate had already expired.<ref>{{cite news |title=Constitutional Court throws out treason charges against ex-president Klaus |author=Rob Cameron |date=March 28, 2013 |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/section/curraffrs/constitutional-court-throws-out-treason-charges-against-ex-president-klaus |publisher=[[Radio Praha]]}}</ref>
==Impeachment process== The [[President of the Czech Republic]] can only be [[impeach]]ed in the case of an act of [[treason]] (which is not defined in the [[Constitution of the Czech Republic|constitution]] itself). The process must be initiated in the Senate, which has the exclusive power to impeach the president, and then passes to the [[Constitutional Court of the Czech Republic|Constitutional Court]], which determines whether the President is guilty or not. If the president is found guilty then they are stripped of their office and may not be elected president again.<ref>[http://www.psp.cz/docs/laws/constitution.html Ústava České republiky]. Psp.cz. Retrieved 2013-07-12.</ref>
==Background== [[Václav Klaus]] was [[Czech presidential election, 2003|elected in 2003]] and [[Czech presidential election, 2008|won his second term in 2008]]. His term ended in March 2013 as he was ineligible to run for another term. Before his term ended, he announced an amnesty to mark the 20th anniversary of the Czech Republic's independence. The amnesty took effect on 2 January and released all prisoners sentenced to one year or less whose sentences had not been served, and all prisoners over 75 years of age sentenced to ten years or less whose sentences had not been served, as well as cancelling all court proceedings which had been ongoing for longer than eight years. The amnesty was widely criticised by the public.<ref name="Vaclav Klaus's controversial amnesty">{{cite web|title=Vaclav Klaus's controversial amnesty|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2013/01/czech-politics|website=The Economist|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=en}}</ref>
The amnesty sparked a public petition to persuade the Czech Senate to charge President Klaus with [[treason]] before the [[Constitutional court]],<ref name="treason">{{cite news|date=4 March 2013|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-21660234|title=Czech President Vaclav Klaus faces treason charge|website=BBC News|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> effectively impeaching him.<ref name=NFPK>{{cite web|title=Appeal for Impeachment against President Vaclav Klaus according to Article 65 of the Constitution|url=http://www.klausovavelezrada.cz/en/|work=NFPK|publisher=NFPK|accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref> Within 24 hours of its launch, it had collected 24,500 signatures, and by the beginning of February 2013, the petition had been signed by more than 64,000 people.<ref name=Aktualne.cz>{{cite web|title=Chtěji žalobu na Klause, mohou být v knize rekordů|url=http://aktualne.centrum.cz/domaci/politika/clanek.phtml?id=769788|work=Aktualne.cz|publisher=Aktualne.cz|accessdate=8 February 2013}}</ref>
==Impeachment== The process started on 4 March 2018, three days before Klaus' term expired. 38 Senators voted in favour, and 30 voted against.<ref name="Klaus se bude zpovídat z velezrady. Senátoři ho žalují u Ústavního soudu">{{cite web|title=Klaus se bude zpovídat z velezrady. Senátoři ho žalují u Ústavního soudu|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/senat-podal-ustavni-zalobu-na-prezidenta-klause-ft7-/domaci.aspx?c=A130304_094103_domaci_kop|website=iDNES.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|date=4 March 2013}}</ref> The court rejected the motion as Klaus' term had already expired and he thus could not be charged with treason.<ref name="Klaus za velezradu souzený nebude, Ústavní soud řízení zastavil">{{cite web|title=Klaus za velezradu souzený nebude, Ústavní soud řízení zastavil|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/ustavni-soud-rozhodl-o-zalobe-na-klause-fc4-/domaci.aspx?c=A130327_163151_domaci_jj|website=iDNES.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|date=27 March 2013}}</ref>
==Reactions== Constitutional experts were uncertain whether the former President could be impeached.<ref name="Ústavní experti se neshodují, zda může žaloba na Klause pro velezradu uspět">{{cite web|title=Ústavní experti se neshodují, zda může žaloba na Klause pro velezradu uspět|url=https://www.novinky.cz/domaci/295032-ustavni-experti-se-neshoduji-zda-muze-zaloba-na-klause-pro-velezradu-uspet.html|website=Novinky.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=cs-CZ}}</ref><ref name="Je možné za velezradu soudit exprezidenta? Ústavní právníci se neshodnou">{{cite web|last1=Eliášová|first1=Kateřina|title=Je možné za velezradu soudit exprezidenta? Ústavní právníci se neshodnou|url=https://domaci.ihned.cz/c1-59439340-experti-se-neshodnou-v-otazce-zaloby-na-vaclava-klause|website=Hospodářské noviny|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=cs-CZ|date=4 March 2013}}</ref> Some experts suggested that the motion had little chance of success as Klaus' actions were unlikely to be considered treason. However, Jan Kudrna expressed the view that the motion had some chance.<ref name="Senát může s žalobou na Klause uspět, míní expert. Jiní nesouhlasí">{{cite web|title=Senát může s žalobou na Klause uspět, míní expert. Jiní nesouhlasí|url=https://zpravy.idnes.cz/experti-se-neshodnou-na-uspechu-zaloby-na-klause-f6o-/domaci.aspx?c=A130304_183954_domaci_jj|website=iDNES.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|date=4 March 2013}}</ref> Severe conducted a survey of Czech lawyers as to whether Klaus was guilty; 75% responded that he was not guilty while 16.7% responded that he was.<ref name="Klaus a velezrada? Asi stejně absurdní jako činit vlaštovky odpovědné za příchod jara.">{{cite web|title=Klaus a velezrada? Asi stejně absurdní jako činit vlaštovky odpovědné za příchod jara.|url=http://ceskapozice.lidovky.cz/klaus-a-velezrada-asi-stejne-absurdni-jako-cinit-vlastovky-odpovedne-za-prichod-jara-g39-/hlas-elity.aspx?c=A130315_110709_pozice_104134|website=Lidovky.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|date=21 March 2013}}</ref>
Klaus' successor [[Miloš Zeman]], who had not agreed with the amnesty, described the impeachment attempt as a "hysterical reaction" and "absurd". He noted that treason is not clearly defined by the Constitution but amnesty is a constitutional power given to the President by the Constitution.<ref name="Žaloba na Klause je hysterickou reakcí, míní Zeman">{{cite web|title=Žaloba na Klause je hysterickou reakcí, míní Zeman|url=https://www.novinky.cz/domaci/295038-zaloba-na-klause-je-hysterickou-reakci-mini-zeman.html|website=Novinky.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=cs-CZ}}</ref> [[Miroslav Kalousek]], known as a vehement opponent of Klaus' politics, condemned the impeachment attempt as "gigantic stupidity".<ref name="Návrh žaloby na Klause pro velezradu podepsalo 27 senátorů">{{cite web|title=Návrh žaloby na Klause pro velezradu podepsalo 27 senátorů|url=https://www.novinky.cz/domaci/294440-navrh-zaloby-na-klause-pro-velezradu-podepsalo-27-senatoru.html|website=Novinky.cz|accessdate=11 February 2018|language=cs-CZ}}</ref>

The bombing, which wounded five others, targeted Alexandria's security chief.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/24/egypt-blast-bomb-kills-two-in-alexandria-ahead-of-presidential-vote.html|title=Bomb kills two in Alexandria ahead of Egypt presidential vote|website=CNBC|date=24 March 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/world/egypt-kills-six-militants-from-group-it-accuses-over-alexandria-bombing|title=Egypt kills six militants from group it accuses over Alexandria bombing|website=The Straits Times|date=26 March 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/world/middle-east/policeman-killed-in-pre-election-bomb-attack-in-egypts-alexandria|title=2 policeman killed in pre-election bomb attack in Egypt's Alexandria|website=The Straits Times|date=24 March 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018}} * '''2 November''' - [[2018 Minya bus attack]]: At least eight Christian Copts were killed and 13 injured when gunmen opened fire on them when they were travelling by bus from the city of Sohag to St. Samuel’s monastery, Islamic State claimed responsibility.{{Cite news|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/11/egypt-deadly-attack-bus-headed-coptic-christian-monastery-181102134431364.html|title=Egypt: Deadly attack on bus near Coptic Christian monastery|work=AlJazeera|accessdate=2018-11-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/attack-on-christians-in-egypt-kills-seven/4640092.html|title=Coptic Church: Attack on Christians in Egypt Kills 14|work=Voanews|accessdate=2018-11-02}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/gunmen-in-egypt-attack-bus-carrying-christians-killing-at-least-7-and-wounding-14/2018/11/02/cadb679b-ab2f-4e28-98f0-47abd40f32fd_story.html?utm_term=.1efb0b580ef4|title=Gunmen in Egypt attack bus carrying Christians, killing at least 8 and wounding 13|work=WashingtonPost|accessdate=2018-11-02}} ==Casualties== {| class="wikitable" align="right" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Year ! Deaths ! Injuries |- | 2013 || 103 || Unknown |- | 2014 || 195 || Unknown |- | 2015 || 272 || Unknown |- | 2016 || 101 || Unknown |- | 2017 || 106|| Unknown |- | 2018 || 7 || 5 |- ! Total || 739 || Unknown |} 103 people were killed in 2013, 195 in 2014, 272 in 2015, 101 in 2016, and at least 160 in 2017. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Egypt Protests and Revolutions}} {{Post-Cold War African conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Insurgency in Egypt (2013-present)}} [[Category:2013 in Egypt]] [[Category:2014 in Egypt]] [[Category:2015 in Egypt]] [[Category:2016 in Egypt]] [[Category:2017 in Egypt]] [[Category:2018 in Egypt]] [[Category:Arab Winter in Egypt]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2013]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2014]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2015]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2016]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2017]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2018]] [[Category:Egyptian crisis (2011–14)]] [[Category:Politics of Egypt]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Egypt]] [[Category:Islamic terrorism]] [[Category:Terrorism in Egypt]] [[Category:Ongoing insurgencies]]

journal|last1=Pawakapan|first1=Puangthong R.|title=The Central Role of Thailand's Internal Security Operations Command in the Post-Counterinsurgency Period|journal=Trends in Southeast Asia|date=November 2017|issue=17|url=https://www.iseas.edu.sg/images/pdf/TRS17_17.pdf|isbn= 978-981-4786-81-2|accessdate=15 November 2017|publisher=Yusof Ishak Institute|location=Singapore|issn=0219-3213}} |preceding1 = Central Security Command (CSC) |preceding2 = Communist Suppression Operations Command (CSOC) |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = Nationwide |headquarters = Ruen Ruedi Palace, Nakhon Ratchasima Road, [[Dusit District|Dusit]], [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]] |coordinates = |region_code = TH |employees = |budget = 10,410.4 million baht (FY2017) |minister1_name = General [[Prayut Chan-o-cha]] |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = |chief1_position = |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |agency_type = [[Government agency]] |parent_agency = [[Office of the Prime Minister (Thailand)|Office of the Prime Minister]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= [[s:Internal Security Act, BE 2551 (2008)|Internal Security Act, BE 2551 (2008)]] |website = {{url|www.isocthai.go.th/}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The '''Internal Security Operations Command''' (ISOC) ({{lang-th|กองอำนวยการรักษาความมั่นคงภายในราชอาณาจักร}}; {{RTGS|''kong am nuai kan raksa khwam man khong phai nai''}} ) or '''ISOC''' ({{lang-th|กอ.รมน.}}; {{rtgs|''kooromono''}}) is the political arm of the [[Thailand|Thai]] military.{{cite news|title=Thailand's Deep State—The Military|url=https://www.asiasentinel.com/politics/thailand-military-deep-state/|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=Asia Sentinel|date=2017-11-14}} It was responsible for suppression of leftist groups during the 1970s and 1980s during which it was implicated in atrocities against activists and civilians. ISOC was implicated in a plot to assassinate Prime Minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]].{{CN|date=June 2016}} After Thaksin was deposed in a [[2006 Thailand coup|military coup]], the junta transformed the ISOC into a "government within a government", giving it wide-reaching authority over the [[National Anti-Corruption Commission (Thailand)|National Anti-Corruption Commission]], the [[Department of Special Investigation]], and the [[Anti-Money Laundering Office (Thailand)|Anti-Money Laundering Office]] (AMLO). The junta also authorized it to help provincial authorities in marketing [[One Tambon One Product|OTOP]] products.''Bangkok Post'', [http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=116776 CNS advises extended term for AEC], 14 February 2007{{failedverification|date=November 2017}} In June 2007, the junta approved a draft national security bill which gave ISOC sweeping powers to handle "new forms of threats" to the country. The ISOC revamp modelled it after the US [[Department of Homeland Security]], and gave ISOC sweeping new powers to allow the ISOC chief to implement security measures such as searches without seeking approval from the prime minister.{{cite news|title=Cabinet approves security bill|url=http://pages.citebite.com/v1y8j7i9g0hsu|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=Bangkok Post|date=2007-06-20}} As of June 2007, ISOC was headed by Army Commander-in-Chief and [[CDRM|junta]] head General [[Sonthi Boonyaratglin]]. ISOC operates under the aegis of the [[Office of the Prime Minister (Thailand)|Office of the Prime Minister]].{{cite web|title=Agencies under OPM|url=http://www.opm.go.th/opmportal//index.asp?pageid=1629&parent=1629&directory=12153&pagename=content1|website=Office of the Prime Minister|accessdate=15 November 2017}} ISOC's [[Fiscal year|FY2017]] budget is 10,410.4 million [[Thai baht|baht]].{{cite book|title=Thailand's Budget in Brief, Fiscal Year 2017|date=2016|publisher=Bureau of the Budget (Thailand)|url=http://www.bb.go.th/budget_book/e-Book2560/FILEROOM/CABILIBRARY60/DRAWER01/GENERAL/DATA0000/%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%93%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%87%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%82%E0%B8%9B%202017-Eng.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222111120/http://www.bb.go.th/budget_book/e-Book2560/FILEROOM/CABILIBRARY60/DRAWER01/GENERAL/DATA0000/%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%9A%E0%B8%9B%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B0%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%93%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%87%E0%B9%80%E0%B8%82%E0%B8%9B%202017-Eng.pdf|archivedate=22 February 2017|df=}}{{RP|80}} ISOC has about 5,000-6,000 staff nationwide, excluding those working in the south, and there are 500,000-600,000 internal security volunteers, as well as tens of thousands of people in its information network.{{cite news|last1=Raksaseri|first1=Kornchanok|title=Isoc power boost 'not political'|url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1391986/isoc-power-boost-not-political|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=Bangkok Post|date=8 January 2018}} ==Communist Suppression Operations Command== The Communist Suppression Operations Command (CSOC) was established in 1965 with the assistance of the United States to coordinate nationwide anti-communist operations.{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Terence C|title=The Causes of Military Insubordination: Explaining Military Organizational Behavior in Thailand|url=http://www.spp.nus.edu.sg/docs/wp/wp0508.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611101420/http://www.spp.nus.edu.sg/docs/wp/wp0508.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=11 June 2007|publisher=Presented at the 46th Annual Meeting of the International Studies Association Honolulu, Hawaii, March 2005|page=22|accessdate=15 November 2017|date=28 February 2005}}{{cite journal|last1=Murray|first1=Charles|title=The Domino That Didn't Fall; Why in a Country Riven by Coups Did an Apparently Robust and Growing Insurgency Collapse?|journal=Atlantic Monthly|date=November 1984|page=34|url=http://contemporarythinkers.org/charles-murray/essay/domino-didnt-fall/|accessdate=15 November 2017|publisher=Contemporary Thinkers}} Following the 17 November 1971 coup by military dictators [[Thanom Kittikachorn]] and [[Praphas Charusathien]], Praphas appointed himself interior minister, chief of police, and head of CSOC. The CSOC was implicated in several atrocities in its 1970s war against leftist groups. This included the [[Red Drum Massacre]], the mass murder of southern Thai activists by burning them alive in gasoline drums.{{CN|date=June 2016}} Student leader [[Thirayuth Boonmee]] showed evidence that the destruction of [[Ban Na Sai]] village, [[Bueng Kan District]], [[Nong Khai Province]] ({{Asof|2011}}, [[Bueng Kan Province]]) in northeast Thailand{{cite web|title=THE BAN NA SAI AFFAIR BECOMES A CAUSE CELEBRE|url=https://www.wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/1974BANGKO02686_b.html|website=Public Library of US Diplomacy|publisher=Wikileaks|accessdate=16 November 2017|date=1974-02-15}} was the handiwork of the CSOC.[http://72.14.209.104/search?q=cache:Ty0mUjArhCcJ:www.newleftreview.net/%3Fgetpdf%3DNLR17702+%22Ban+Na+Sai%22+Thailand+communist&hl=en&gl=us&ct=clnk&cd=2&client=firefox-a Anderson, Benedict, "Murder and Progress in Modern Siam"]{{DL|date=November 2017}} The military had earlier claimed that the [[Communist Party of Thailand]] (CPT) was responsible for the village's destruction.{{CN|date=June 2016}} CSOC's name was changed to ISOC in 1974. ==Operations during the 1970s== ISOC conducted operations in cities and the Thai countryside to subvert leftist groups through propaganda and violence.{{cite book|last1=Handley|first1=Paul M|title=The King Never Smiles: A Biography of Thailand's Bhumibol Adulyadej|date=2006|publisher=Yale University Press, 2006|location=New Haven|isbn=0300106823|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=x6VDmAEACAAJ&dq=0300106823&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtof2TyMHXAhUQSo8KHYMrAqMQ6AEIJzAA|page=222|accessdate=15 November 2017}} In 1973, the ISOC commenced a bombing campaign against hill tribe villages in northern Thailand.{{CN|date=June 2016}} Prime Minister to-be [[Prem Tinsulanonda]] was a senior officer of the ISOC.{{CN|date=June 2016}} ISOC's role declined starting in the early-1980s after the downfall of the CPT. However, it still had great influence. On 1 April 1987, after Prime Minister [[Kukrit Pramoj]] claimed that ISOC had been brainwashed by communists, over 200 Thai Army Rangers attacked the prime minister's residence.{{cite web|url=http://www.asiatour.com/thailand/e-01land/et-lan73.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120721224621/http://www.asiatour.com/thailand/e-01land/et-lan73.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 July 2012 |title=THAILAND - |publisher= |accessdate=12 March 2017 }}{{failed verification|date=November 2017}} ==Plot to assassinate Thaksin Shinawatra== ISOC Deputy Director [[Pallop Pinmanee]] was sacked{{cite news|title='Fake bomb' at Thai leader's home|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5291984.stm|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=BBC News|date=28 August 2006}} after Lieutenant [[Thawatchai Klinchana]],{{cite news|title='Bomb' found near Thai PM's home|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5280788.stm|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=BBC News|date=2006-08-24}} his driver, was found driving a car containing 67 kilograms of explosives near the residence of Prime Minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]. Pallop denied all involvement, noting that "If I was behind it, I would not have missed."{{cite news|title='If I was behind it, PM would be dead'|url=http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/08/25/national/national_30011902.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105130053/http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/08/25/national/national_30011902.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-11-05|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=The Nation|date=2006-08-25}} Metropolitan Police Bureau commissioner Lt General [[Wiroj Jantharangsee]] noted that the explosives in the car were completely assembled, equipped with a remote sensor ready to be detonated, and would have had a blast radius of around one kilometre.{{CN|date=November 2017}} ==Post-2006-coup ISOC== Thaksin planned a major restructuring of the ISOC prior to the coup which overthrew him in September 2006. Soon after the coup, the junta released three army suspects in the car bomb plot.{{cite news|title=Car-bomb suspects get bail|url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/09/30/headlines/headlines_30015051.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180101/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2006/09/30/headlines/headlines_30015051.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2016-03-03|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=The Nation|date=2006-09-30}} [[CDRM|Junta]] leader and Army Commander-in-Chief General [[Sonthi Boonyaratglin]] appointed himself head of ISOC (its previous head had been the prime minister) and transformed ISOC into a "government within a government". The new ISOC was criticized as being a shadowy puppet master pulling the strings of existing agencies, answerable to no one but its leader.''The Nation'', [http://www.nationmultimedia.com/search/page.news.php?clid=5&id=30021304 Thailand's Dept of Homeland Security] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929105501/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/search/page.news.php?clid=5&id=30021304 |date=2007-09-29 }}, 12 December 2006{{failed verification|date=November 2017}} To protect people in south Thailand from [[South Thailand insurgency|insurgency-related violence]], ISOC produced [[Jatukham Rammathep]] amulets for distribution to the Buddhist minority. The renowned animist amulets were believed to have magical powers to protect their wearers from violence and large sums are paid for them. The plan was developed by Colonel Manas Khongpan, deputy director of ISOC in [[Yala Province]].''The Nation'', [http://nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/14/national/national_30029259.php Amulets to 'help protect' Buddhists in South] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175605/http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2007/03/14/national/national_30029259.php |date=2016-03-03 }}, 14 March 2007{{failed verification|date=November 2017}} The cabinet of General [[Surayud Chulanont]] gave 732 ISOC staff members an 84.3 million baht "reward" in mid-2007. ISOC explained that police and soldiers were temporarily transferred to support ISOC's operation. ISOC wanted to reward them for their hard work and sacrifice. ISOC had originally requested the reward in 2003, but was turned down by the Thaksin government.{{cite news|title=Cabinet backs B84.3m in Isoc 'rewards'|url=http://pages.citebite.com/v1l9r8e4s9evv|accessdate=15 November 2017|work=Bangkok Post|date=2007-07-23}} ===Bases=== * Tambon Khao Toom in [[Yarang District]] of [[Pattani Province]] is the site of [[Fort Sirindhorn]], headquarters of ISOC Area 4.{{cite news |title=Outgoing and new Army chiefs visit Pattani |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30354127 |accessdate=11 September 2018 |work=The Nation |date=11 September 2018}} ==See also== *[[Office of the Prime Minister (Thailand)]] *[[Deep State]] *[[Operation Gladio]] *''[[The King Never Smiles]]'' == References == {{Reflist}} {{National Intelligence Agencies}} [[Category:Political history of Thailand]] [[Category:Thai intelligence agencies]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1966]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Thailand]] [[Category:State agencies of Thailand]] [[Category:Political and cultural purges]]

page.title: LGBT rights in the Northern Mariana Islands

revision.comment: /* Discrimination protections and hate crime laws */
revision.text:
{{Infobox LGBT rights | location_header = Northern Mariana Islands | image = LocationNorthernMarianas.png | caption = [[Northern Mariana Islands]] | legal_status = Legal for both men and women since 1983 | gender_identity_expression = Transgender persons allowed to change gender following surgery | recognition_of_relationships = Same-sex marriage since 2015 | adoption = Since 2015 | discrimination_protections = No }} '''[[Lesbian]], [[gay]], [[bisexual]], and [[transgender]] ([[LGBT]]) people in the [[Northern Mariana Islands]]''' may face legal challenges and discrimination not faced by non-LGBT people. [[Same-sex marriage]] and [[LGBT adoption|adoption]] became legal with the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court's]] ruling in the case of ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]'' in June 2015. However, the [[United States|U.S.]] territory does not ban discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
==History== The [[Chamorro people]] have traditionally accepted homosexuality and transgender people. The [[Chamorro language|Chamorro]] word for a gay man is ''mamflorita'' (literally ''little flowers'').<ref>[https://guides.library.manoa.hawaii.edu/Pacificsexualidentity Gender identity and Sexual Identity in the Pacific and Hawai'i: Introduction]</ref>
==Legality of same-sex sexual activity== Same-sex sexual activity has been legal in the Northern Marianas since 1983.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gay rights map: Notes on the data|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-26016267|accessdate=November 3, 2014|work=BBC News|date=February 5, 2014}}</ref>
==Recognition of same-sex relationships== {{main article|Same-sex marriage in the Northern Mariana Islands}}
Same-sex marriage became legal in the Commonwealth on June 26, 2015, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that it is unconstitutional to ban same-sex marriages. Prior to this, there was no prohibition on same-sex marriage in the law of the territory, nor do the statutes specify the sex of the parties to a marriage between citizens of the Northern Mariana Islands.<ref>{{cite web|title=Commonwealth Code|url=http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|publisher=Northern Mariana Islands Law Revision Commission|accessdate=April 21, 2015|at=Title 8 Section 1205|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520110659/http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|archivedate=May 20, 2016|df=}}</ref> Other provisions assume the parties to a marriage are not of the same sex. With respect to a marriage involving one or more non-citizens, the statutes say: "The male at the time of contracting the marriage be at least 18 years of age and the female at least 16 years of age..."<ref>{{cite web|title=Commonwealth Code|url=http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|publisher=Northern Mariana Islands Law Revision Commission|accessdate=April 21, 2015|at=Title 8 Section 1201|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520110659/http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|archivedate=May 20, 2016|df=}}</ref> Statutes concerning divorce assume that the partners to a marriage are man and wife.<ref>{{cite web|title=Commonwealth Code|url=http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|publisher=Northern Mariana Islands Law Revision Commission|accessdate=April 21, 2015|quote=A divorce from marriage may be granted ... for the following causes ... Willful neglect by the husband to provide suitable support for his wife when able to do so|at=Title 8 Section 1331|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520110659/http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|archivedate=May 20, 2016|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Commonwealth Code|url=http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|publisher=Northern Mariana Islands Law Revision Commission|accessdate=April 21, 2015|quote=In actions for dissolution of marriage, neither the domicile nor residence of the husband shall be deemed to be the domicile or residence of the wife....|at=Title 8 Section 1332|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160520110659/http://www.cnmilaw.org/frames/Commonwealth%20Code.html|archivedate=May 20, 2016|df=}}</ref> These laws have yet to be changed to reflect the Supreme Court ruling.
The first marriage between a same-sex couple occurred on the island of [[Saipan]] on July 22, 2015.<ref>[http://www.mvariety.com/cnmi/cnmi-news/local/78637-apatang-officiates-first-same-sex-marriage-on-saipan Apatang officiates first same-sex marriage on Saipan]</ref>
==Discrimination protections and hate crime law== The Northern Mariana Islands does not protect people from discrimination on the basis of their [[sexual orientation]] and/or [[gender identity]]. Additionally, the territory does not ban hate crimes based on sexual orientation and gender identity. However, such [[hate crime]]s are banned federally under the ''[[Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/28/obama-signs-hate-crimes-bill/|title=Obama Signs Hate Crimes Bill|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=September 29, 2013}}</ref>
Lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender persons are allowed to serve openly in the American Armed Forces.<ref>[http://www.nbcnews.com/id/43859711/ns/us_news-life/ Obama certifies end of military's gay ban]</ref>
==Gender identity and expression== Transgender persons in the Northern Mariana Islands may change their legal gender following [[sex reassignment surgery]] and a name change. The ''Vital Statistics Act of 2006'', which took effect in March 2007, states that: "Upon receipt of a certified copy of an order of the CNMI Superior Court indicating the sex of an individual born in the CNMI has been changed by surgical procedure and whether such individual’s name has been changed, the certificate of birth of such individual shall be amended as prescribed by regulation." <ref>{{cite act |title= Vital Statistics Act of 2006 |type= Public Law |number= 15-50|language= English |date= 2006 | url=http://www.cnmilaw.org/pdf/public_laws/15/pl15-50.pdf |accessdate= 12 August 2015}}</ref>
==Living conditions== The first pride parade in the Northern Mariana Islands was held in July 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/lgbt-celebrates-gay-pride-at-gig/ |title=LGBT celebrates Gay Pride at GIG|website=Saipan Tribune|date=August 1, 2018}}</ref>
Since legalization in June 2015, the territory has become a popular marriage destination for same-sex couples, especially among [[China|Chinese]] tourists. In the first half of 2018, 77% of all marriages were same-sex marriages.<ref>[https://www.saipantribune.com/index.php/same-sex-tourism-still-all-the-rage-in-cnmi/ Same-sex tourism still all the rage in CNMI]</ref>
